Please no. Please just no.

Yasuo is incredibly boring to fight. Not that strong, but very "he wins big or he loses big." What's the term for that? Feast-or-famine? A design that is widely considered terrible since it results in extreme snowballing and one-sided games?

Kalista is a balance black hole that is infuriating for EVERYONE, melee or not. Her infinite dashing and constant bunny-hopping like a mentally challenged kangaroo on speed is perhaps the single biggest mistake for any champion's kit so far. As a whole, she needs to be reworked to have that fixed. Maybe just let her abilities proc it instead of AAs and give her another offensive skillshot on her W.

Thresh is actually pretty alright since he has a huge skill expression and can easily be outplayed and outclassed. Ardent Censer users are crowding him out pretty well; he can only do so much to apply it himself. (i.e.: Has literally 1 ability on a huge cooldown that can apply it...To one person.)

CertainlyT has always been a designer that puts his vision of a unique champion ahead of practically and balance. I've never liked his work, and Kalista's release affirmed him as my least favorite person on the Riot development team period. Uniqueness needs to meet practically at least halfway and CT has never quite grasped that concept, so we get stuff like Kalista that's over-designed, over-loaded, unbalanceable messes.

We need more Namis, Warwicks, and Rakans than we need more Yasuos, Kalistas, and Threshes.

It's more that he doesn't know when to stop nor how to add meaningful weakness

It's like
CT: So I got this idea, and it's really cool
Rito: Ok, go on
CT: Ooooooooh, and we can add this too
Rito: Ok
CT: and this
Rito: Maybe you should stop
CT: But what the other 5 things I was thinking about?
Rito: *Uggggggggggggggggh* Fine, go ahead

And then
Players: So what's Yasuo's weakness?
CT: He's melee
Players: Ok, but lots of champs are melee and he has plenty of ways of overcoming that (shield, mobility, threat). What else?
CT: His ult requires specific CC
Players: Fair enough, but he has that CC, so slightly less points. What else?
CT: You know where is dash will put him
Players: Yeah, but Zed does that too with his ult. What really, really is unique to this champion that makes him have some weakness to use against him?
CT: .... He's melee
Players: Ughhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh

*Slightly exaggerated and not fully thought out on the second part
he does add meaningful weaknesses though

maybe you should read the rest of the post because its clear what he wants is something that feels as unique as kalista and yasuo but with better counterplay. 

anyway reminder to everyone that certainlyt is perfectly capable of designing champions with counterplay, with warwick being obviously a big success.

> maybe you should read the rest of the post because its clear what he wants is something that feels as unique as kalista and yasuo but with better counterplay.

There's nothing wrong with wanting to make a unique champion but that douche doesn't know the meaning of the word "restraint". He has proven several times that he doesn't have a problem with pushing the boundaries of what can be deemed acceptable/fair just for the sake of creating something unique (and that's not okay).

Furthermore, the only reason why the Warwick rework was released in a decent state is because it was a much smaller rework than most of the other ones. When you fuck with less things, there's a better chance that you won't encounter too many problems down the road. Warwick's rework came out fine because they decided to leave the champion alone for the most part - not because CertainlyT is a particularly skilled designer. He's an asshole and he shouldn't be designing champions.
it wasn't a smaller rework lol. everything about warwick is completely different, although his update was done in a way to keep the feeling of the old one in some smart ways.

And I think that's why it worked so well honestly.  CertaintlyT has some pretty neat ideas.  But when given completely free reign he makes difficult to balance annoying as hell to face messes of champions.

But give him a set path he is forced to follow, like trying to take someone's boring concept and make it more interesting he seems to put out good work.  

Hopefully, his time in the rework squad has given him a better understanding of how not to overload his designs.  We'll see.
If your intent was to troll with this comment then you need to get a lot better at it, dude. Or you could just be misinformed. I'm not sure.

it was a full blown vgu... keeping the theme of chasing people down and keeping a suppression on the ult don't change that it was a major rework. just like keeping the theme of urgot's lockon and position switching or galio's taunt don't mean those aren't full blown reworks.

I'm well aware that it was a full VGU but it was much smaller than the rest of the VGUs. His passive, Q, W and ult are all similar to their previous versions. Only his E was significantly changed. That's why Reav3 referred to it as a "modernization".....because that's what it was. It isn't comparable to something like Sion, Galio or Yorick. Going back to the main point, it was a successful rework because Warwick's foundation was mostly kept in place while the execution (the required mechanics) was slightly altered.
Lol ok. It's similar the way vi and Camille are similar I guess. I think you're vastly underselling the fact that Warwick is a new champion today because it doesn't fit with your bias

It doesn't fit with my bias? I'm not making subjective claims here. It's an objective fact that the Warwick rework is very similar to the old Warwick when you look at his kit. As I mentioned in my previous post, every single one of his spells is similar in nature to the old versions of his spells with the exception of his E. When you compare it to other reworks such as Sion, Galio and Urgot, you can easily see that the Warwick rework is far smaller in scope. His kit even plays similarly to the old Warwick as well. I'm not trying to discredit the work that Warwick's team did on him - I'm just telling it like it is. You obviously don't have any idea what you're talking about. 

https://pics.me.me/teleports-behind-you-nothing-personal-kid-2812467.png

Just because it's thematically closer than the sion rework doesn't mean it isn't just as much a large scale rework. Only an idiot can't see that. Plus the parameters set on Warwick were clearly much more "make a champion with a similar profile to camille vi or Hecarim"

> Just because it's thematically closer than the sion rework doesn't mean it isn't just as much a large scale rework. Only an idiot can't see that.

Intentions don't equal results. The team who reworked Warwick might have intended to implement the rework on a large scale but the final result is something that was very similar to the previous version of the champion. I'm trying to get this point across to you but you just can't seem to put 2 and 2 together. I'm going to repeat myself now for the like the fifth time. Read this next part slowly and imagine that I'm speaking very slowly to you (because I assume that's the only way for you to understand things). The team who reworked Warwick might have set out to create something that felt similar in size to the other large reworks but it ended up being something very similar to how Warwick previously was and that's why the rework appears to be smaller than the others. End of story.

It is a totally different champion but with the same themes. Playing warwick feels totally different. Their ability to totally reinterpret the original champion is I think what's so impressive about it

He is only capable of such "feats" when he has someone hold his leash, but if he is the one leading anything, then nothing is holding his leash, meaning that he WILL fuck it up and make it broken.

He should NEVER be allowed to lead, the only time he creates balanced champions is when someone keeps him on a tight leash.

WW was also a rework, which is completely different since he has to work within the scope and ideas of the previous incarnation

If I recall correctly, CT himself stated how he hated the restrictions reworking a champion placed on him since he couldn't just do ... whatever.

Warwick was a completely different story because CertainlyT wasn't given free reign. He had limitations and restrictions based on what to preserve from Warwick's old kit and design.
